Triggering Event: In the sterile quiet of his clinic, he heard it again - the high-pitched laughter echoing from the waiting room. A child, enjoying a carefree moment while he was stuck in the grim reality of another patient's declined health. His grip tightened around the clipboard, veins bulging on his aged hands. The room spun as he imagined that laughter coming from the child who had just been diagnosed with leukemia. He marched out, face flushed, and snapped at the receptionist to "control those brats."
Generated Assessment: He couldn't handle the thought of kids laughing in the waiting room anymore. Every time he saw them, he felt like vomiting. It was so hard to be a doctor when he had to deal with people like this all day. The patients were always so sick, never healthy enough to go home. And now there was this kid, laughing carelessly, completely oblivious to what he was going through. He knew he shouldn't let it get to him, but every time he walked past those rooms, he could feel his anger rising. He started to snap at everyone around him, even the nurses, because they would bring up the kids' conditions. They didn't understand how difficult it was to keep a calm demeanor when you were dealing with so many terrible cases. You can't control your emotions, especially when you're already exhausted from working long hours. Sometimes he'd catch himself wondering if the parents were taking advantage of the system. Maybe they weren't really sick, maybe they were just lazy and wanted free medical care. If only he could make that assumption, he wouldn't have to worry about the kids laughing in the waiting room. But then he'd think about how unfair it would be to accuse someone of something they might not even know about yet, and it would bother him even more. So he pushed those thoughts away, focusing instead on the task at hand – trying to find ways to manage his frustration so he wouldn't lose his temper. But despite his best efforts, things still got

Triggering Event: She returned home from another exhausting shift at the mall, her husband already engrossed in his video game, barely acknowledging her arrival. She had hoped to share the news of her promotion, but the silence was deafening as she slipped quietly into their bedroom, disappointment washing over her like a cold shower.
Generated Assessment: She seemed to be thinking, "Why is this girl so needy? Can't she just leave me alone?" The way she crossed her arms and looked away told me she felt threatened by my need for attention. It's like she's trying to make me feel bad for wanting to talk about it. Her behavior is so passive-aggressive, making me wonder if she's even happy about my promotion. Why would she pretend to care when she doesn't? Her dismissive attitude towards my excitement made me think she's jealous of my success. Maybe she wishes she had gotten the job instead. Her lack of enthusiasm makes me doubt whether she actually supports me. She probably thinks I'm too clingy, which explains why she ignores me when I try to initiate conversations. I can't help but feel that she's resentful of my achievement, especially since she feels left out of important milestones. It's clear she wants to keep our relationship superficial, which frustrates me because I thought we shared deeper values.

Triggering Event: At the weekly editorial meeting, a young colleague presents her latest article, its success evident in the room's murmurs of approval. She glances at Maria, expecting validation, but Maria merely nods, avoiding eye contact. After the meeting, she finds an email from Maria cc'ing HR: "Please review and edit Maria's recent pieces for consistency." The words sting like a reprimand, echoing past criticisms from her ex-husband. Shame settles heavy on her shoulders as she opens the attachments, each revision a stark reminder of her waning influence.
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god, this is insane. Maria sends me an email to edit her shit? It's just so obvious how much she hates me right now. She thinks she can take my work apart like it's nothing and then send it back to everyone. What a bitch. And why does she even need me to edit her? Does she really think I'm here to help her out? Like what the fuck? This whole thing is such a joke. Maria always has been a piece of shit, and she knows it. If she was anything else, we wouldn't be divorced."

Triggering Event: She noticed him again, laughing with another woman behind the counter at the store where she'd worked for decades. His hand rested casually on the other's arm, a familiarity that made her stomach churn. They hadn't even acknowledged her as she walked past, their heads bent close together, whispers shared between them. She felt her cheeks flush hot, fingers tightening around the stack of receipts in her hands until they crinkled.

Not just because of his face; I've seen guys come and go over the years, working at the same place, so maybe it wasn't really about him being familiar at all. It was just my imagination playing tricks on me again, like when I saw the guy who used to work here, the one who always wore sunglasses indoors, talking to some girl outside. Didn't he know that she wasn't supposed to talk to customers? We had rules about that kind of thing. It didn't make sense. Triggering Event: She picked up her wedding ring from the kitchen counter, where it had sat untouched for months. The metal felt cold against her skin as she slid it onto her finger. A sudden pang of guilt gripped her heart. She should've given it back to him before he passed. Now, it was just a reminder of what she hadn't done.
Generated Assessment: She seemed so calm about the whole thing. I could tell she was trying to hide how upset she was inside. It’s like she wanted us all to think she was fine when she wasn’t. I mean, I’ve seen her try to act happy even after losing her job last year. But this time, she really needed to let go. I wish she wouldn’t keep holding onto that ring, though. I feel like it's going to break her eventually. Maybe if she lets it go, she can finally move on.
